title.native: 魔法使いになれなかった女の子の話。
title.romaji: Mahoutsukai ni Narenakatta Onnanoko no Hanashi.
title.english: The Stories of Girls Who Couldn't Be Magicians

description:
At Rettoran Magic Academy, two unlikely friends share one dream: to become magicians. Kurumi is an average girl who’s a bit naive, while Yuzu is the distinguished daughter of a noble magician family. They need to get into a special magician training class, but they fail the entrance exam! All hope seems lost until mysterious homeroom teacher Minami Suzuki arrives, and their luck takes a sudden turn.

(Source: Crunchyroll)
synonyms: Story of a Girl that was Unable to Become a Mage.

tags.description: Features a wealthy, high-class, oftentimes stuck up and demanding female character.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/TkashiWatanabe)

Joined Top Craft as an animator while still attending university, switched his focus to directing in the late '80s.

Married to [Miyata Naomi](https://anilist.co/staff/220081/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/hoshino_lily)

Lily Hoshino, alternatively named Ririi Hoshino, is a Japanese mangaka, doujin artist, illustrator and character designer known for her extremely cute art style featured in her many published manga, some of which are shounen-ai. She also does illustrations for yuri magazines.

On January 25, 2016, Lily announced that she had gotten married, while later in March 2019, she gave birth to a baby boy.

Longtime video game composer for Square Co., Ltd. and arguably one of the most prolific female game composers in the world, Yoko Shimomura is behind the music for games such as Legend of Mana and Parasite Eve. She is likely best known for her work on the Kingdom Hearts series and the Mario & Luigi series.

**Hayato Matsuo** is a Japanese arranger, composer, orchestrator and musician. Hayato is a composer, arranger and orchestrator for both the video game industry and the anime industry. He has worked on titles such as Front Mission 3, Final Fantasy XII, the Shenmue Series, and Magic Knight Rayearth. Inspired by his mother, who was a piano teacher, he graduated from the music composition department of Tokyo University of the Arts. While in college, he composed for the band G-Clef, and occasionally stood in for the members of the band. Upon graduating, he went to work under Sugiyama Kouichi, the composer of the popular Dragon Quest video game series, arranging his pieces for Dragon Quest anime shows and soundtracks. In 1991, Hayato began to work as a video game music composer himself, writing the score to Master of Monsters. Over the next few years, he worked as an independent composer on several games and anime series, including Ogre Battle: March of the Black Queen. In 1995, he joined the independent music composition group Imagine. He has continued since then to compose and orchestrate works for over 20 games and anime shows, as well as the television show Kamen Rider 555, and a few pieces a part of original albums.
Affiliated with [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/), where he is one of the art directors.

__Website | Twitter | Instagram | YouTube__ Introduction: Halca is a Japanese musician affiliated with company Music Ray'n and signed to label Sacra Music. She had a major appearance as the opening act during the CHiCO with HoneyWorks 2017 tour. In 2018 she released her first single called "Kimi no Tonari", which was used as the ending theme for the anime "Wotakoi: Love is Hard for Otaku". Her other appearances have been in anime such as: Ace Attorney, Kaguya-sama: Love is War and We Never Learn!: BOKUBEN Season 2 Biography: Halca started with an interest in music from early childhood. She was heavily inspired when she one day received a copy of the song "Again" by YUI. While in junior high school, she discovered that her home's cable TV had an anime channel, which is also the way she became familiar with anime music in general. She would watch this anime channel on a daily basis, which slowly began to impact her future plans. The biggest impact from the several anime shows she watched in her childhood, were shows such as Cardcaptor Sakura and Toradora!. The anime that had the biggest musical influence ended up being the song "Kiss Kara Hajimaru Miracle" from the anime Steel Angel Kurumi, which became her favorite anime song. She decided to join her school's choir club and broadcast theater club later on to hone her vocal skills, as she started to take an approach to singing herself. After honing her skills in school she officially decided to pursue a career as a musician. Halca had a lot of singing auditions to consider, but the audition that piqued her interest the most was for the Utakatsu! Audition, which focused on anime songs. She decided to participate in the audition for Utakatsu!, and she ended up winning the grand prize in 2013. She didn't let win go to her head, however, as after the winning the audition she continued to train her vocal skills while waiting to make her major debut. In 2017 she was invited by the singer CHiCO, known primarily for her involvement in the group HoneyWorks (alongside Gom, Shito and Yamako), to perform in the latter's 2017 live tour as their opening act. Following her opening act, she performed the song "Kimi no Sora" ("Your Sky"), which was included in a compilation album released to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the online novel publisher Noichigo. She also performed with the song "Resonator", which was used in the original soundtrack for the anime series "Beatless", and she also made a mini-album titled White Disc, which was sold during the HoneyWorks tour. Halca made her major debut later in 2018, with the release of her first single "Kimi no Tonari" ("Next to You"), which was used as the ending theme for the anime Wotakoi: Love is Hard for Otaku. To commemorate the release of her first single, the mini-album White Disc was made available for sale during the single's release event. Her second single "Starting Blue" was released in October 2018, with the title track being used as the ending theme for the second season of the anime Ace Attorney. Her third single "Sentimental Crisis" was released in February 2019, the title track was used as the ending theme for the anime Kaguya-sama: Love is War. Her fourth single "Houkago no Liberty" was released on November 13, 2019, the title track was used as the ending theme to the anime We Never Learn!: BOKUBEN Season 2. (Source: [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halca), edited)

__[Website](https://tooboe.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/tooboeofficial) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9rPALOT-ZVc7VEXATYSNCA)__

__TOOBOE__ is a Japanese solo unit consisting of the vocaloid producer, vocalist, lyricist and composer [John](https://twitter.com/casablancalanca).

Puffy (romanized as PUFFY in Japan) or Puffy AmiYumi is a Japanese rock duo that is currently signed with Sony Music Japan. The group continues to go by the moniker of PUFFY in Japan, but in order to avoid legal naming conflicts with Sean Combs, it has adopted the name Puffy AmiYumi outside of Japan. They sing in Japanese and English.  [Ami Oonuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101448/), whose nickname is Jane, and [Yumi Yoshimura](https://anilist.co/staff/101449), nicknamed Sue, were scouted by Sony-affiliated talent agencies and put together in the mid-1990s. The band gained mainstream success in Japan during 1998, following the release of their Jet album and tour in support of it.  Their first release "Asia no Junshin" sold a million records and their success has continued with several more full-length releases (totaling 14 million sales in Japan).
